title: 107_s2541
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes provisions for aggravated identity theft. The "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" introduces provisions for aggravated identity theft, including penalties for knowingly transferring, possessing, or using another person's identification without lawful authority during felony violations. Offenders face additional imprisonment terms of 2 years for general offenses and 5 years for terrorism-related offenses. The "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" imposes a 5-year imprisonment term for aggravated identity theft. The act prohibits probation for offenders and mandates consecutive sentences for related crimes. The "Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" mandates that the term of imprisonment for a violation of this section may run concurrently with another term imposed for an additional violation of this section. The term "felony violation enumerated in subsection (c)" refers to any felony offense listed in subsection (c). The term "violation enumerated in subsection (c)" refers to felony offenses including theft from employee benefit plans, false personation of citizenship, false statements in connection with firearm acquisition, fraud and false statements, mail, bank, and wire fraud, nationality and citizenship, passports and visas, and violations of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. The curr_chunk lists specific sections of various acts related to obtaining customer information by false pretenses, immigration offenses, and false statements under the Social Security Act. Chapter 47 of Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item after section 1028. Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include possession of identity theft materials and increase the penalty to 5 years. Additionally, facilitating an act of domestic terrorism is added as an offense.
